awd_titl_txt: Spin and Charge Dynamics: Competing Orders and Quasi-Particle Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

Characterizing the properties of quantum materials and their different quantum phases is paramount in order to be able to develop new alternative technologies beyond the semiconductor paradigm for applications in energy conversion, electronic devices, and light harvesting. This award supports research and education that will not only have technological implications but will also tackle fundamental questions in physics that could lead to unanticipated discoveries.

The quest for materials with novel functionality is driven by the study of quantum systems where interactions among the constituent electrons are very strong. These interactions can give rise to complex and intriguing phenomena that take place when the physics is mostly governed by the collective behavior of the electrons inside the material.  One particular example occurs when considering electrons confined in low spatial dimensions: the confinement forces electrons to move by "pushing" instead of passing around each other. Same as oscillations of a string, the natural excitations of such a confined system of electrons can be better understood in terms of waves. As a consequence, electrons lose their individual identities as particles. This project focuses on understanding how electrons lose or recover their identities as individual excitations and how their behavior is subsequently transformed, giving rise to different phases in the material.

Even though these problems are theoretically very challenging due to their underlying complexity, they are amenable to numerical methods. The focus of the research is computational in nature and will also involve the development of new innovative algorithms based on quantum information and machine-learning ideas. New tools for scientific discovery will be developed and will be made available to the community as open-source software that may find applications in other disciplines beyond condensed matter physics.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award will support research and education focused on tackling urgent questions concerning different instabilities in strongly correlated materials due to the presence of antiferromagnetic long-range order and van Hove singularities. This project tackles a paradigmatic problem in condensed matter from a new perspective. In order to overcome the limitations of the Mermin-Wagner theorem, chains and ladders will be studied in the presence of long-range interactions that can realize actual spontaneous symmetry breaking and true antiferromagnetic order. The research will address questions of a very fundamental nature: i) How do spinons evolve into magnons and what are their signatures in the excitation spectrum? ii) Is it possible to realize fractionalized excitations and coherent excitations simultaneously in different regions of the Brillouin zone? iii) How do coherent quasiparticles form (if at all), in the presence of long-range order? Will we still observe signatures of spin-charge separation in the spectrum? iv) What is the interplay between long-range antiferromagnetic order and pairing? v) What terms in the Hamiltonian would give rise to competing instabilities such as those observed in superconducting cuprates? The method of choice will be the density matrix renormalization group and its time-dependent variants, which were co-developed by the PI and have had a remarkable success expanding our knowledge of correlation effects to the time domain.

This work is complemented by the development of novel computational approaches to tackle higher-dimensional systems based on new original ideas that bridge quantum information and machine learning: i) The use of lapped orthogonal orbitals that interpolate between real- and momentum-space representations, ii) Quantum disentanglers and natural orbitals to construct the wave functions of the elementary quasiparticle excitations, and iii) Using restricted Boltzmann machines to calculate the single-particle Green's functions, and therefore reconstruct the entire excitation spectrum of the quantum many-body problem. These new tools will be made available to the community as open-source software that may find applications in other disciplines beyond condensed matter physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum magnetism and criticality:  Much research has been devoted to one-dimensional systems, a scenario where many interesting problems admit an exact solution and  where disorder can give rise to phenomena such as many-body localization, and integrability can lead to lack of ergodicity and thermalization. Numerical techniques based on matrix product states are particularly well suited to study this kind of problems. On the other hand, some crucial aspects make two dimensional problems particularly interesting: the Mermin-Wagner theorem establishes that local Hamiltonians cannot realize symmetry breaking in one dimension, and that this can occur in two dimensions only at zero temperature. This makes one-dimension somewhat ill-suited to study phenomena such as symmetry breaking and quantum phase transitions in magnetic or superconducting systems. Two dimensional dystems can also realize exotic phases without long range order but, unlike ``mundane'' Luttinger liquids, they can be as exotic as spin liquids with emergent gauge fields and fractionalized excitations. During the course of the this funding period, the PI has taken an unconventional route to tackle this problem, by introducing unfrustrating long range interactions that have the following effects: (i) they effectively increase the dimensionality of the problem through all-to-all interactions; (ii) overcome the limitations of Mermin-Wagner theorem allowing one to probe for true long range order and spontaneous symmetry breaking; (iii) the systems can realize true quasi-particles and undergo a transition between Luttinger liquid and Fermi liquid; (iv) they offer a relatively simple and intuitive playground where to test for higher dimensional physics within the reach of powerful numerical techniques such as the density matrix renormalization group (DMRG). Through this approach, we have been able to study the dimensional crossover and the physics of higher dimensional systems using one dimensional models that are easier to treat numerically and theoretically. We have been able to determine how the excitation spectrum evolves across a phase transition from a spin liquid to ordered antiferromagnet, the transition from a topological state into an ordered phase in ladders with long-range interactions, and how spin and charge excitations in a Luttinger liquid with spin-charge separation bind to form coherent fermionic quasiparticles. These developments indicate a simple and elegant approach to identify relevant interactions and machanisms behind quasi-particl fractionalization, pseudo-gap formation and in general, to describe much of the phenomenology of 2D models that can be instrumental to describe the physics of cuprate superconductors.  

Machine Learning inspired methods to study quantum dynamics of many-body systems: Neural networks have successfully been used as variational wave function approximators to model the ground state of many-body quantum systems. The input of the neural network is a quantum many-body configuration and the output is its wave-function amplitude. Therefore, the neural network is effectively compressing all the information about a quantum many-body state in a few parameters defined by its internal weights and biases. The most promising results were initially achieved with restricted Boltzmann machines (RBM), a type of artificial neural network widely used in machine learning. During the last two years, the PI's group has made remarkable progress toward developing computational methods using neural networks as variational estimators. In particular, we conceived an algorithm to calculate spectral functions using a correction vector method, and a second one using a Chebyshev expansion that has been successfully applied to relatively large one dimensional spin systems. We have introduced a natural gradient descent approach to solve linear systems of equations and use Monte Carlo to obtain the dynamical correlation function. The method is general and can be extended to other variational forms. These approaches indicate promising routes to calculate quantities that are experimentally relevant in two  dimensional systems.

Funds from past and current NSF grants have fully or partially supported the PI, 6 graduate students working on topics in theoretical and computational condensed matter physics. The PI also mentored 6 undergraduate students, and lectured in several international schools in India, Argentina, Italy, Taiwan, and the Boulder Summer School. The material of these lectures was summarized in two sets of lecture notes that are published as AIP Proceedings\cite{Vietri} and chapters in a book. The PI continues the support of the DMRG ALPS code through its mailing list, and organizing lectures and workshops, such as the one in Argentina. The PI has also been organizing the very successful series of on-line Quantum Matter Seminars streamed via Zoom and YouTube, and collaborated with the NU Center for STEM Education through the Boston Public Schools Science Fair and Young Scholar Program.
